\CommentTok{#>  [5] fitted.values assign        qr            df.residual  }
\CommentTok{#>  [9] xlevels       call          terms         model        }
\CommentTok{#> <0 rows> (or 0-length row.names)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

If you've used other OO languages, this might make you feel queasy. But
surprisingly, this flexibility causes few problems: while you \emph{can}
change the type of an object, you never \emph{should}. R doesn't protect
you from yourself: you can easily shoot yourself in the foot. As long as
you don't aim the gun at your foot and pull the trigger, you won't have
a problem.

To avoid foot-bullet intersections when creating your own class, you
should always provide:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  A \textbf{constructor}, \texttt{new\_x()}, that efficiently creates
  new objects with the correct structure.
\end{itemize}

For more complicated classes, you may also want to provide:

\begin{itemize}
\item
  A \textbf{validator}, \texttt{validate\_x()}, that performs more
  expensive checks that the object has correct values.
\item
  A \textbf{helper}, \texttt{x()}, that provides a convenient and neatly
  parameterised way for others to construct and validate (create)
  objects of this class.
\end{itemize}

\hypertarget{constructors}{%
\subsection{Constructors}\label{constructors}}

S3 doesn't provide a formal definition of a class, so it has no built-in
way to ensure that all objects of a given class have the same structure
(i.e.~same attributes with the same types). Instead, you should enforce
a consistent structure yourself by using a \textbf{constructor}. A
constructor is a function whose job is to create objects of a given
class, ensuring that they always have the same structure.

There are three rules that a constructor should follow. It should:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  Be called \texttt{new\_class\_name()}.
\item
  Have one argument for the base object, and one for each attribute.
  (More if the class can be subclassed, see
  \protect\hyperlink{inheritance-1}{inheritance}.)
\item
  Check the types of the base object and each attribute.
\end{enumerate}

Base R generally does not provide constructors (three exceptions are the
internal \texttt{.difftime()}, \texttt{.POSIXct()}, and
\texttt{.POSIXlt()}) so we'll demonstrate constructors by filling in
some missing pieces in base. (If you want to use these constructors in
your own code, you can use the versions exported by the sloop package,
which complete a few details that we skip here in order to focus on the
core issues.)

We'll start with one of the simplest S3 classes in base R: Date, which
is just a double with a class attribute. The constructor rules lead to
the slightly awkward name \texttt{new\_Date()}, because the existing
base class uses a capital letter. I recommend using lower case class
names to avoid this problem.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{new_Date <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x) \{}
  \KeywordTok{stopifnot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{is.double}\NormalTok{(x))}
  \KeywordTok{structure}\NormalTok{(x, }\DataTypeTok{class =} \StringTok{"Date"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{\}}

\KeywordTok{new_Date}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{-}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{))}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "1969-12-31" "1970-01-01" "1970-01-02"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

You can use the \texttt{new\_s3\_*()} helpers provided by the sloop to
make this even simpler. They are wrappers around structure that require
a class argument, and check the base type of \texttt{x}.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{new_Date <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x) \{}
\NormalTok{  sloop}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{new_s3_dbl}\NormalTok{(x, }\DataTypeTok{class =} \StringTok{"Date"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The purpose of the constructor is to help the developer (you). That
means you can keep them simple, and you don't need to optimise the error
messages for user friendliness. If you expect others to create your
objects, you should also create a friendly helper function, called
\texttt{class\_name()}, that we'll describe shortly.

A slightly more complicated example is \texttt{POSIXct}, which is used
to represent date-times. It is again built on a double, but has an
attribute that specifies the time zone, a length 1 character vector. R
defaults to using the local time zone, which is represented by the empty
string. To create the constructor, we need to make sure each attribute
of the class gets an argument to the constructor. This gives us:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{new_POSIXct <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x, }\DataTypeTok{tzone =} \StringTok{""}\NormalTok{) \{}
  \KeywordTok{stopifnot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{is.double}\NormalTok{(x))}
  \KeywordTok{stopifnot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{is.character}\NormalTok{(tzone), }\KeywordTok{length}\NormalTok{(tzone) }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
  
  \KeywordTok{structure}\NormalTok{(x, }
    \DataTypeTok{class =} \KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"POSIXct"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"POSIXt"}\NormalTok{),}
    \DataTypeTok{tzone =}\NormalTok{ tzone}
\NormalTok{  )}
\NormalTok{\}}

\KeywordTok{new_POSIXct}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "1970-01-01 00:00:01 UTC"}
\KeywordTok{new_POSIXct}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{tzone =} \StringTok{"UTC"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "1970-01-01 00:00:01 UTC"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The constructor checks that \texttt{x} is a double, and that
\texttt{tzone} is a length 1 character vector. We use
\texttt{stopifnot()} here since the constructor is a developer focussed
function so error messages don't need to be that friendly. Note that
POSIXct uses a class \emph{vector}; we'll come back to what that means
in \protect\hyperlink{inheritance-1}{inheritance}.

Generally, the constructor should not check that the values are valid
because such checks are often expensive. For example, our
\texttt{new\_POSIXct()} constructor does not check that \texttt{tzone}
is a valid value, and we get a warning when the object is printed.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{x <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{new_POSIXct}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Auckland NZ"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{x}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "1970-01-01 00:00:01 Auckland"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{validators}{%
\subsection{Validators}\label{validators}}

More complicated classes will require more complicated checks for
validity. Take factors, for example. The constructor function only
checks that the structure is correct:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{new_factor <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x, levels) \{}
  \KeywordTok{stopifnot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{is.integer}\NormalTok{(x))}
  \KeywordTok{stopifnot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{is.character}\NormalTok{(levels))}
  
  \KeywordTok{structure}\NormalTok{(}
\NormalTok{    x,}
    \DataTypeTok{levels =}\NormalTok{ levels,}
    \DataTypeTok{class =} \StringTok{"factor"}
\NormalTok{  )}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

So it's possible to use this to create invalid factors:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{new_factor}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\OperatorTok{:}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"a"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> Error in as.character.factor(x):}
\CommentTok{#>   malformed factor}
\KeywordTok{new_factor}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{0}\OperatorTok{:}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"a"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> Error in as.character.factor(x):}
\CommentTok{#>   malformed factor}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Rather than encumbering the constructor with complicated checks, it's
better to put them in a separate function. This is a good idea because
it allows you to cheaply create new objects when you know that the
values are correct, and to re-use the checks in other places.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{validate_factor <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x) \{}
\NormalTok{  values <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{unclass}\NormalTok{(x)}
\NormalTok{  levels <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{attr}\NormalTok{(x, }\StringTok{"levels"}\NormalTok{)}
  
  \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ (}\OperatorTok{!}\KeywordTok{all}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{!}\KeywordTok{is.na}\NormalTok{(values) }\OperatorTok{&}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{values }\OperatorTok{>}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{)) \{}
    \KeywordTok{stop}\NormalTok{(}
      \StringTok{"All `x` values must be non-missing and greater than zero"}\NormalTok{,}
      \DataTypeTok{call. =} \OtherTok{FALSE}
\NormalTok{    )}
\NormalTok{  \}}
  
  \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ (}\KeywordTok{length}\NormalTok{(levels) }\OperatorTok{<}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{max}\NormalTok{(values)) \{}
    \KeywordTok{stop}\NormalTok{(}
      \StringTok{"There must at least as many `levels` as possible values in `x`"}\NormalTok{,}
      \DataTypeTok{call. =} \OtherTok{FALSE}
\NormalTok{    )}
\NormalTok{  \}}
  
\NormalTok{  x}
\NormalTok{\}}

\KeywordTok{validate_factor}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{new_factor}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\OperatorTok{:}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"a"}\NormalTok{))}
\CommentTok{#> Error: There must at least as many `levels` as possible values in `x`}
\KeywordTok{validate_factor}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{new_factor}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{0}\OperatorTok{:}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"a"}\NormalTok{))}
\CommentTok{#> Error: All `x` values must be non-missing and greater than zero}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This function is called primarily for its side-effects (throwing an
error if the object is invalid) so you'd expect it to invisibly return
its primary input. However, unlike most functions called for their side
effects, its useful for validation methods to return visibly, as we'll
see next.

\hypertarget{helpers}{%
\subsection{Helpers}\label{helpers}}

If you want others to construct objects from your class, you should also
provide a helper method that makes their life as easy as possible. This
should have the same name as the class, and should be parameterised in a
convenient way. \texttt{factor()} is a good example of this as well: you
want to automatically derive the internal representation from a vector.
The simplest possible implementation looks something like this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{factor <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x, }\DataTypeTok{levels =} \KeywordTok{unique}\NormalTok{(x)) \{}
\NormalTok{  ind <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{match}\NormalTok{(x, levels)}
  \KeywordTok{validate_factor}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{new_factor}\NormalTok{(ind, levels))}
\NormalTok{\}}
\KeywordTok{factor}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"a"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"a"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"b"}\NormalTok{))}
\CommentTok{#> [1] a a b}
\CommentTok{#> Levels: a b}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The validator prevents the construction of invalid objects, but for a
real helper you'd spend more time creating user friendly error messages.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{factor}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"a"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"a"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"b"}\NormalTok{), }\DataTypeTok{levels =} \StringTok{"a"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> Error: All `x` values must be non-missing and greater than zero}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

In base R, neither \texttt{Date} nor \texttt{POSIXct} has a helper
function. Instead there are two ways to construct them:

\begin{itemize}
\item
  By coercing from another type with \texttt{as.Date()} and
  \texttt{as.POSIXct()}. These functions should be S3 generics, so we'll
  come back to them in \protect\hyperlink{coercion-1}{coercion}.
\item
  With a helper function that either parses a string
  (\texttt{strptime()}) or creates a date from individual components
  (\texttt{ISODatetime()}).
\end{itemize}

These missing helpers mean that there's no obvious default way to create
a date or date-time in R. We can fill in those missing pieces with a
couple of helpers:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{Date <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(year, month, day) \{}
  \KeywordTok{as.Date}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{ISOdate}\NormalTok{(year, month, day, }\DataTypeTok{tz =} \StringTok{""}\NormalTok{))}
\NormalTok{\}}

\NormalTok{POSIXct <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(year, month, day, hour, minute, sec, }\DataTypeTok{tzone =} \StringTok{""}\NormalTok{) \{}
  \KeywordTok{ISOdatetime}\NormalTok{(year, month, day, hour, minute, sec, }\DataTypeTok{tz =}\NormalTok{ tzone)}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

These helpers fill a useful role, but are not computationally efficient:
behind the scenes \texttt{ISODatetime()} works by pasting the components
into a string and then using \texttt{strptime()}. More efficient
equivalents are \texttt{lubridate::make\_datetime()} and
\texttt{lubridate::make\_date()}.

\hypertarget{object-styles}{%
\subsection{Object styles}\label{object-styles}}

S3 gives you the freedom to build a new class on top of any existing
base type. So far, we've focussed on vector-style where you take an
existing vector type and add some attributes. Importantly, a single
vector-style object represents multiple values. There are two other
important styles: scalar-style and data-frame-style.

Each \textbf{scalar}-style object represents a single ``value'', and are
built on top of named lists. This is the style that you are most likely
to use in practice. The constructor for the scalar type is slightly
different because the arguments become named elements of the list,
rather than attributes.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{new_scalar_class <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x, y, z) \{}
  \KeywordTok{structure}\NormalTok{(}
    \KeywordTok{list}\NormalTok{(}
      \DataTypeTok{x =}\NormalTok{ x,}
      \DataTypeTok{y =}\NormalTok{ y,}
      \DataTypeTok{z =}\NormalTok{ z}
\NormalTok{    ),}
    \DataTypeTok{class =} \StringTok{"scalar_class"}
\NormalTok{  )}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

(For a real constructor, you'd also check that the \texttt{x},
\texttt{y}, and \texttt{z} fields are the types that you expect.)

In base R, the most important example of this style is \texttt{lm}, the
class returned when you fit a linear model:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{mod <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{lm}\NormalTok{(mpg }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{wt, }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ mtcars)}
\KeywordTok{typeof}\NormalTok{(mod)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "list"}
\KeywordTok{names}\NormalTok{(mod)}
\CommentTok{#>  [1] "coefficients"  "residuals"     "effects"       "rank"         }
\CommentTok{#>  [5] "fitted.values" "assign"        "qr"            "df.residual"  }
\CommentTok{#>  [9] "xlevels"       "call"          "terms"         "model"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The \textbf{data-frame-style} builds on top of a data frame (a named
list where each element is a vector of the same length), and adds
additional attributes to store important metadata. A data-frame-style
constructor looks like:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{new_df_class <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(df, attr1, attr2) \{}
  \KeywordTok{stopifnot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{is.data.frame}\NormalTok{(df))}
  
  \KeywordTok{structure}\NormalTok{(}
\NormalTok{    df, }
    \DataTypeTok{attr1 =}\NormalTok{ attr1,}
    \DataTypeTok{attr2 =}\NormalTok{ attr2,}
    \DataTypeTok{class =} \KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"df_class"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"data.frame"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{  )}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The most common data-frame-style class is the tibble, a modern
reimagining of the data frame provided by the tibble package, and used
extensively within the tidyverse.

Collectively, we'll call the attributes of a vector-style or
data-frame-style class and the names of a list-style class the
\textbf{fields} of an object.

When creating your own classes, you should pick the vector style if your
class closely resembles an existing vector type. Otherwise, use a scalar
(list) style. The scalar type is generally easier to work with because
implementing a full range of convenient vectorised methods is usually a
lot of work. It's typically obvious when you need to use a
data-frame-style.

\hypertarget{exercises-40}{%
\subsection{Exercises}\label{exercises-40}}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\item
  Categorise the objects returned by \texttt{lm()}, \texttt{factor()},
  \texttt{table()}, \texttt{as.Date()}, \texttt{ecdf()},
  \texttt{ordered()}, \texttt{I()} into ``vector'', ``scalar'', and
  ``other''.
\item
  Write a constructor for \texttt{difftime} objects. What base type are
  they built on? What attributes do they use? You'll need to consult the
  documentation, read some code, and perform some experiments.
\item
  Write a constructor for \texttt{data.frame} objects. What base type is
  a data frame built on? What attributes does it use? What are the
  restrictions placed on the individual elements? What about the names?
\item
  Enhance our \texttt{factor()} helper to have better behaviour when one
  or more \texttt{values} is not found in \texttt{levels}. What does
  \texttt{base::factor()} do in this situation?
\item
  Carefully read the source code of \texttt{factor()}. What does it do
  that our constructor does not?
\item
  What would a constructor function for \texttt{lm} objects,
  \texttt{new\_lm()}, look like? Why is a constructor function less
  useful for linear models?
\end{enumerate}

\hypertarget{generics-and-methods}{%
\section{Generics and methods}\label{generics-and-methods}}

The job of an S3 generic is to perform method dispatch, i.e.~find the
function designed to work specifically for the given class. S3 generics
have a simple structure: they call \texttt{UseMethod()}, which then
calls the right method. \texttt{UseMethod()} takes two arguments: the
name of the generic function (required), and the argument to use for
method dispatch (optional). If you omit the second argument it will
dispatch based on the first argument, which is what I generally advise.
\indexc{UseMethod()} \index{S3!new generic}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{# Dispatches on x}
\NormalTok{generic <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x, y, ...) \{}
  \KeywordTok{UseMethod}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"generic"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{\}}

\CommentTok{# Dispatches on y}
\NormalTok{generic2 <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x, y, ...) \{}
  \KeywordTok{UseMethod}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"generic2"}\NormalTok{, y)}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Note that you don't pass any of the arguments of the generic to
\texttt{UseMethod()}; it uses black magic to pass them on automatically.
Generally, you should avoid doing any computation in a generic, because
the semantics are complicated and few people know the details. In
general, any modifications to the arguments of the generic will be
undone, leading to much confusion.

A generic isn't useful without some methods, which are just functions
that follow a naming scheme (\texttt{generic.class}). Because a method
is just a function with a special name, you \emph{can} call methods
directly, but you generally \emph{shouldn't}. The main reason to call
the method directly is that it sometimes leads to considerable
performance improvements. See \protect\hyperlink{be-lazy}{performance}
for an example.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{generic.foo <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x, y, ...) \{}
  \KeywordTok{message}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"foo method"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{\}}

\KeywordTok{generic}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{new_s3_scalar}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{class =} \StringTok{"foo"}\NormalTok{))}
\CommentTok{#> foo method}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

You can see all the methods defined for a generic with
\texttt{s3\_methods\_generic()}:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{s3_methods_generic}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"generic"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> # A tibble: 2 x 4}
\CommentTok{#>   generic class    visible source    }
\CommentTok{#>   <chr>   <chr>    <lgl>   <chr>     }
\CommentTok{#> 1 generic foo      TRUE    .GlobalEnv}
\CommentTok{#> 2 generic skeleton TRUE    methods}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Note the false positive: \texttt{generic.skeleton()} is not a method for
our generic but an existing function in the methods package. It's picked
up because method definition relies only on a naming convention. This is
another reason that you should avoid using \texttt{.} in non-method
function names.

Remember that apart from methods that you've created, and those defined
in the base package, most S3 methods will not be directly accessible.
You'll need to use \texttt{getS3method("generic",\ "class")} to see
their source code.

\hypertarget{coercion}{%
\subsection{Coercion}\label{coercion}}

Many S3 objects can be naturally created from an existing object through
\textbf{coercion}. If this is the case for your class, you should
provide a coercion function, an S3 generic called
\texttt{as\_class\_name}. Base R generally does not follow this
convention, which can cause problems as illustrated by
\texttt{as.factor()}:

\begin{itemize}
\item
  The name is confusing, since \texttt{as.factor()} is not the
  \texttt{factor} method of the \texttt{as()} generic.
\item
  \texttt{as.factor()} is not a generic, which means that if you create
  a new class that could be usefully converted to a factor, you can not
  extend \texttt{as.factor()}.
\end{itemize}

We can fix these issues by creating a new generic coercion function and
providing it with some methods:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{as_factor <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x, ...) \{}
  \KeywordTok{UseMethod}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"as_factor"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Every \texttt{as\_y()} generic should have a \texttt{y} method that
returns its input unchanged:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{as_factor.factor <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x, ...) x}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This ensures that \texttt{as\_factor()} works if the input is already a
factor.

Two useful methods would be for character and integer vectors.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{as_factor.character <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x, ...) \{}
  \KeywordTok{factor}\NormalTok{(x, }\DataTypeTok{levels =} \KeywordTok{unique}\NormalTok{(x))}
\NormalTok{\}}
\NormalTok{as_factor.integer <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x, ...) \{}
  \KeywordTok{factor}\NormalTok{(x, }\DataTypeTok{levels =} \KeywordTok{as.character}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{unique}\NormalTok{(x)))}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Typically the coercion methods will either call the constructor or the
helper; pick the function that makes the code simpler. Here the helper
is simplest. If you use the constructor, remember to also call the
validator function.

If you think your coercion function will be frequently used, it's worth
providing a default method that gives a better error message. Default
methods are called when no other method is appropriate, and are
discussed in more detail in
\protect\hyperlink{inheritance-1}{inheritance}.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{as_factor}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> Error in UseMethod("as_factor"):}
\CommentTok{#>   no applicable method for 'as_factor' applied to an object of class "c('double', 'numeric')"}

\NormalTok{as_factor.default <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x, ...) \{}
  \KeywordTok{stop}\NormalTok{(}
    \StringTok{"Don't know how to coerce object of class "}\NormalTok{, }
    \KeywordTok{paste}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{(x), }\DataTypeTok{collapse =} \StringTok{"/"}\NormalTok{), }\StringTok{" into a factor"}\NormalTok{, }
    \DataTypeTok{call. =} \OtherTok{FALSE}
\NormalTok{  )}
\NormalTok{\}}
\KeywordTok{as_factor}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> Error: Don't know how to coerce object of class numeric into a factor}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{s3-arguments}{%
\subsection{Arguments}\label{s3-arguments}}

Methods should always have the same arguments as their generics. This is
not usually enforced, but it is good practice because it will avoid
confusing behaviour. If you do eventually turn your code into a package,
R CMD check will enforce it, so it's good to get into the habit now.

There is one exception to this rule: if the generic has \texttt{...},
the method must still have all the same arguments (including
\texttt{...}), but can also have its own additional arguments. This
allows methods to take additional arguments, which is important because
you don't know what additional arguments that a method for someone
else's class might need. The downside of using \texttt{...}, however, is
that any misspelled arguments will be silently swallowed.

\hypertarget{exercises-41}{%
\subsection{Exercises}\label{exercises-41}}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\item
  Read the source code for \texttt{t()} and \texttt{t.test()} and
  confirm that \texttt{t.test()} is an S3 generic and not an S3 method.
  What happens if you create an object with class \texttt{test} and call
  \texttt{t()} with it? Why?

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{x <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{structure}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\OperatorTok{:}\DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{class =} \StringTok{"test"}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{t}\NormalTok{(x)}
\CommentTok{#> }
\CommentTok{#>  One Sample t-test}
\CommentTok{#> }
\CommentTok{#> data:  x}
\CommentTok{#> t = 6, df = 9, p-value = 3e-04}
\CommentTok{#> alternative hypothesis: true mean is not equal to 0}
\CommentTok{#> 95 percent confidence interval:}
\CommentTok{#>  3.33 7.67}
\CommentTok{#> sample estimates:}
\CommentTok{#> mean of x }
\CommentTok{#>       5.5}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\item
  Carefully read the documentation for \texttt{UseMethod()} and explain
  why the following code returns the results that it does. What two
  usual rules of function evaluation does \texttt{UseMethod()} violate?

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{g <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x) \{}
\NormalTok{  x <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{10}
\NormalTok{  y <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{10}
  \KeywordTok{UseMethod}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"g"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{\}}
\NormalTok{g.default <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x) }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{x =}\NormalTok{ x, }\DataTypeTok{y =}\NormalTok{ y)}

\NormalTok{x <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{1}
\NormalTok{y <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{1}
\KeywordTok{g}\NormalTok{(x)}
\CommentTok{#>  x  y }
\CommentTok{#>  1 10}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\end{enumerate}

\hypertarget{method-dispatch}{%
\section{Method dispatch}\label{method-dispatch}}

At a high-level, S3 method dispatch is simple, and revolves around two
functions, \texttt{UseMethod()} and \texttt{NextMethod()}. You'll learn
about these two functions below, and then we'll come back to some of the
additional wrinkles in \protect\hyperlink{dispatch-details}{dispatch
details}.

\hypertarget{usemethod}{%
\subsection{\texorpdfstring{\texttt{UseMethod()}}{UseMethod()}}\label{usemethod}}

The purpose of \texttt{UseMethod()} is to find the appropriate method to
call given a generic and a class. It does this by creating a vector of
function names,
\texttt{paste0("generic",\ ".",\ c(class(x),\ "default"))}, and looking
for each method in turn. As soon as it finds a matching method, it calls
it. If no matching method is found, it throws an error. To explore
dispatch, we'll use \texttt{sloop::s3\_dispatch()}. You give it a call
to an S3 generic, and it lists all the possible methods, noting which
ones exist. For example, what happens when you try to print a
\texttt{POSIXct} object?

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{x <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{Sys.time}\NormalTok{()}
\KeywordTok{s3_dispatch}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{print}\NormalTok{(x))}
\CommentTok{#> -> print.POSIXct}
\CommentTok{#>    print.POSIXt}
\CommentTok{#>  * print.default}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\texttt{print()} will look for three possible methods, of which two
exist, and one, \texttt{print.POSIXct()}, will be called. The last
method is always the ``default'' method. This doesn't correspond to a
specific class, so is a useful catch all.

\hypertarget{nextmethod}{%
\subsection{\texorpdfstring{\texttt{NextMethod()}}{NextMethod()}}\label{nextmethod}}

Method dispatch usually terminates as soon as a matching method is
found. However, methods can explicitly choose to call the next available
method using \texttt{NextMethod()}. This is useful because it allows you
to rely on code that others have already written, which we'll come back
to in \protect\hyperlink{inheritance-1}{inheritance}. Let's make
\texttt{NextMethod()} concrete with an example. Here, I define a new
generic (``showoff'') with three methods. Each method signals that it's
been called, and then calls the ``next'' method:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{showoff <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x) \{}
  \KeywordTok{UseMethod}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"showoff"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{\}}
\NormalTok{showoff.default <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x) \{}
  \KeywordTok{message}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"showoff.default"}\NormalTok{)}
  \OtherTok{TRUE}
\NormalTok{\}}
\NormalTok{showoff.a <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x) \{}
  \KeywordTok{message}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"showoff.a"}\NormalTok{)}
  \KeywordTok{NextMethod}\NormalTok{()}
\NormalTok{\}}
\NormalTok{showoff.b <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x) \{}
  \KeywordTok{message}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"showoff.b"}\NormalTok{)}
  \KeywordTok{NextMethod}\NormalTok{()}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Let's create a dummy object with classes ``b'' and ``a''.
\texttt{s3\_dispatch()} shows that all three potential methods are
available:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{x <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{new_s3_scalar}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{class =} \KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"b"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"a"}\NormalTok{))}
\KeywordTok{s3_dispatch}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{showoff}\NormalTok{(x))}
\CommentTok{#> -> showoff.b}
\CommentTok{#>  * showoff.a}
\CommentTok{#>  * showoff.default}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

When you call \texttt{NextMethod()} it finds and calls the next
available method in the dispatch list. When we call \texttt{showoff()},
the method for \texttt{b} forwards to the method for \texttt{a}, which
forwards to the default method.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{showoff}\NormalTok{(x)}
\CommentTok{#> showoff.b}
\CommentTok{#> showoff.a}
\CommentTok{#> showoff.default}
\CommentTok{#> [1] TRUE}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Like \texttt{UseMethod()}, the precise semantics of
\texttt{NextMethod()} are complex. It doesn't actually work with the
class attribute of the object, but instead uses a special global
variable (\texttt{.Class}) to keep track of which method to call next.
This means that modifying the argument that is dispatched upon has no
impact, and you should avoid modifying the object that is being
dispatched on.

Generally, you call \texttt{NextMethod()} without any arguments.
However, if you do give arguments, they are passed on to the next
method, as if they'd been supplied to the generic.

\hypertarget{exercises-42}{%
\subsection{Exercises}\label{exercises-42}}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\item
  Which base generic has the greatest number of defined methods?
\item
  Explain what is happening in the following code.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{generic2 <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x) }\KeywordTok{UseMethod}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"generic2"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{generic2.a1 <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x) }\StringTok{"a1"}
\NormalTok{generic2.a2 <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x) }\StringTok{"a2"}
\NormalTok{generic2.b <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x) \{}
  \KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{(x) <-}\StringTok{ "a1"}
  \KeywordTok{NextMethod}\NormalTok{()}
\NormalTok{\}}

\KeywordTok{generic2}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{new_s3_scalar}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{class =} \KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"b"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"a2"}\NormalTok{)))}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "a2"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\end{enumerate}

\hypertarget{inheritance}{%
\section{Inheritance}\label{inheritance}}

The class attribute is not limited to a single string, but can be a
character vector. This, along with S3 method dispatch and
\texttt{NextMethod()}, gives a surprising amount of flexibility that can
be used creatively to reduce code duplication. However, this flexibility
can also lead to code that is hard to understand or reason about, so you
are best constraining yourself to simple styles of inheritance. Here we
will focus on defining subclasses that inherit their fields, and some
behaviour, from a parent class.

Subclasses use a character \textbf{vector} for the class attribute.
There are two examples of subclasses that you might have come across in
base R:

\begin{itemize}
\item
  Generalised linear models are a generalisation of linear models that
  allow the error term to belong to a richer set of distributions, not
  just the normal distribution like the linear model. This is a natural
  case for the use of inheritance and indeed, in R, \texttt{glm()}
  returns objects of class \texttt{c("glm",\ "lm")}.
\item
  Ordered factors are used when the levels of a factor have some
  intrinsic ordering, like \texttt{c("Good",\ "Better",\ "Best")}.
  Ordered factors are produced by \texttt{ordered()} which returns an
  object with class \texttt{c("ordered",\ "factor")}.
\end{itemize}

You can think of the glm class ``inheriting'' behaviour from the lm
class, and the ordered class inheriting behaviour from the factor class
because of the way method dispatch works. If there is a method available
for the subclass, R will use it, otherwise it will fall back to the
``parent'' class. For example, if you ``plot'' a glm object, it falls
back to the lm method, but if you compute the ANOVA, it uses a
glm-specific method.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{mod1 <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{glm}\NormalTok{(mpg }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{wt, }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ mtcars)}

\KeywordTok{s3_dispatch}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{plot}\NormalTok{(mod1))}
\CommentTok{#>    plot.glm}
\CommentTok{#> -> plot.lm}
\CommentTok{#>  * plot.default}
\KeywordTok{s3_dispatch}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{anova}\NormalTok{(mod1))}
\CommentTok{#> -> anova.glm}
\CommentTok{#>  * anova.lm}
\CommentTok{#>    anova.default}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{constructors-1}{%
\subsection{Constructors}\label{constructors-1}}

There are three principles to adhere to when creating a subclass:

\begin{itemize}
\item
  A subclass should be built on the same base type as a parent.
\item
  The \texttt{class()} of the subclass should be of the form
  \texttt{c(subclass,\ parent\_class)}
\item
  The fields of the subclass should include the fields of the parent.
\end{itemize}

And these properties should be enforced by the constructor.

When you create a class, you need to decide if you want to allow
subclasses, because it requires changes to the constructor and careful
thought in your methods. To allow subclasses, the parent constructor
needs to have \texttt{...} and \texttt{subclass} arguments:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{new_my_class <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x, y, ..., }\DataTypeTok{subclass =} \OtherTok{NULL}\NormalTok{) \{}
  \KeywordTok{stopifnot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{is.numeric}\NormalTok{(x))}
  \KeywordTok{stopifnot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{is.logical}\NormalTok{(y))}
  
  \KeywordTok{structure}\NormalTok{(}
\NormalTok{    x,}
    \DataTypeTok{y =}\NormalTok{ y,}
\NormalTok{    ...,}
    \DataTypeTok{class =} \KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(subclass, }\StringTok{"my_class"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{  )}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Then the implementation of the subclass constructor is simple: it checks
the types of the new fields, then calls the parent constructor.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{new_subclass <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x, y, z) \{}
  \KeywordTok{stopifnot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{is.character}\NormalTok{(z))}
  \KeywordTok{new_my_class}\NormalTok{(x, y, z, }\DataTypeTok{subclass =} \StringTok{"subclass"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

If you wanted to allow this subclass to be futher subclassed, you'd need
to include \texttt{...} and \texttt{subclass} arguments:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{new_subclass <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x, y, z, ..., }\DataTypeTok{subclass =} \OtherTok{NULL}\NormalTok{) \{}
  \KeywordTok{stopifnot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{is.character}\NormalTok{(z))}
  
  \KeywordTok{new_my_class}\NormalTok{(x, y, z, ..., }\DataTypeTok{subclass =} \KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(subclass, }\StringTok{"subclass"}\NormalTok{))}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

If your subclass is more complicated, you'd also provide validator and
helper functions, as described previously.

\hypertarget{coercion-1}{%
\subsection{Coercion}\label{coercion-1}}

You also need to make sure that there's some way to convert the subclass
back to the parent class. The best way to do that is to add a method to
the coercion generic. Generally, this method should call the parent
constructor:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{as_my_class.sub_class <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x) \{}
  \KeywordTok{new_my_class}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{attr}\NormalTok{(x, }\StringTok{"x"}\NormalTok{), }\KeywordTok{attr}\NormalTok{(x, }\StringTok{"y"}\NormalTok{))}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{methods}{%
\subsection{Methods}\label{methods}}

The goal of creating a subclass is to reuse as much code as possible
from the parent class. This means that you should not have to define
every method that the parent class provides (if you do, reconsider if
you actually need a subclass!). Generally, defining new methods is
straightforward: you simply create a new method
(\texttt{generic.subclass}) whenever the parent method doesn't do quite
the right thing. In many cases, the new method will be able to call
\texttt{NextMethod()} in order to take advantage of the computation done
in the parent.

One wrinkle arises when you have methods that return the same type of
object as the primary input. For example, dplyr has many functions
(\texttt{arrange()}, \texttt{summarise()}, \texttt{mutate()}, \ldots{})
that input a data frame (or data frame-like object) and output a
modified version of that data frame. Imagine you want to store the
provenance of each data frame, i.e.~who created it and when. To do so,
you might create a data frame subclass called \texttt{provenance}:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{new_provenance <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(data, author, }\DataTypeTok{date =} \KeywordTok{Sys.Date}\NormalTok{()) \{}
  \KeywordTok{stopifnot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{is.data.frame}\NormalTok{(data))}
  \KeywordTok{stopifnot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{is.character}\NormalTok{(author), }\KeywordTok{length}\NormalTok{(author) }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
  \KeywordTok{stopifnot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{is.Date}\NormalTok{(date), }\KeywordTok{length}\NormalTok{(date) }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
  
  \KeywordTok{structure}\NormalTok{(}
\NormalTok{    data,}
    \DataTypeTok{author =}\NormalTok{ author, }
    \DataTypeTok{date =}\NormalTok{ date,}
    \DataTypeTok{class =} \KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"provenance"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"data.frame"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{  )}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

And now you want to make this class work with dplyr. The class doesn't
change any of the computation related to the data frame, it just needs
to preserve the attributes, which dplyr doesn't know anything about.
That means you need to provide a method for each dplyr generic. The
computation is unchanged, so you can use \texttt{NextMethod()} to do all
the hard work, but you need to manually reconstruct the provenance
object.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{arrange.provenance <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(.data, ...) \{}
  \KeywordTok{new_provenance}\NormalTok{(}
    \KeywordTok{NextMethod}\NormalTok{(), }
    \DataTypeTok{author =} \KeywordTok{attr}\NormalTok{(.data, }\StringTok{"author"}\NormalTok{),}
    \DataTypeTok{date =} \KeywordTok{attr}\NormalTok{(.data, }\StringTok{"date"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{  )}
\NormalTok{\}}

\NormalTok{mutate.provenance <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(.data, ...) \{}
  \KeywordTok{new_provenance}\NormalTok{(}
    \KeywordTok{NextMethod}\NormalTok{(), }
    \DataTypeTok{author =} \KeywordTok{attr}\NormalTok{(.data, }\StringTok{"author"}\NormalTok{),}
    \DataTypeTok{date =} \KeywordTok{attr}\NormalTok{(.data, }\StringTok{"date"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{  )}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

To do this for all the dplyr generics would require a lot of copying and
pasting. Let's reduce some of that duplication by taking advantage of
\texttt{sloop::reconstruct()}. \texttt{reconstruct()} is a generic
function designed to reconstruct a subclass from an instance of the
parent class, typically created by \texttt{NextMethod()}, and the
original subclass. In other words, the job of a reconstructor is to take
an object from a parent class, and copy over attributes from the
subclass. (Note that \texttt{reconstruct()} is unusual in that it
dispatches on the second argument. This allows a more natural
specification.)

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{reconstruct.provenance  <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(new, old) \{}
  \KeywordTok{new_provenance}\NormalTok{(}
\NormalTok{    new, }
    \DataTypeTok{author =} \KeywordTok{attr}\NormalTok{(old, }\StringTok{"author"}\NormalTok{),}
    \DataTypeTok{date =} \KeywordTok{attr}\NormalTok{(old, }\StringTok{"date"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{  )}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Now we can rewrite the methods to minimise the amount of duplicated
code:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{arrange.provenance <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(.data, ...) \{}
  \KeywordTok{reconstruct}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{NextMethod}\NormalTok{(), .data)}
\NormalTok{\}}

\NormalTok{mutate.provenance <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(.data, ...) \{}
  \KeywordTok{reconstruct}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{NextMethod}\NormalTok{(), .data)}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This duplicated code could be avoided completely if
\texttt{arrange.data.frame()}, provided by dplyr, called
\texttt{reconstruct()} for you. And indeed, a future version of that
function will.

When designing a class that can be subclassed, you need to carefully
think through these issues. Generally, whenever you implement a method
that returns the same type of object as the primary input, you should
call \texttt{reconstruct()} to ensure that it also works for subclasses.
That way implementors of a subclass will only need to provide methods
when the computation is actually different.

\hypertarget{exercises-43}{%
\subsection{Exercises}\label{exercises-43}}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\item
  The \texttt{ordered} class is a subclass of \texttt{factor}, but it's
  implemented in a very ad hoc way in base R. Implement it in a
  principled way by building a constructor and an \texttt{as\_ordered}
  generic.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{f1 <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{factor}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"a"}\NormalTok{, }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"a"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"b"}\NormalTok{))}
\KeywordTok{as.factor}\NormalTok{(f1)  }
\CommentTok{#> [1] a}
\CommentTok{#> Levels: a b}
\KeywordTok{as.ordered}\NormalTok{(f1) }\CommentTok{# loses levels}
\CommentTok{#> [1] a}
\CommentTok{#> Levels: a}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\item
  What classes have a method for the \texttt{Math} group generic in base
  R? Read the source code. How do the methods work?
\item
  R has two classes for representing date time data, \texttt{POSIXct}
  and \texttt{POSIXlt}, which both inherit from \texttt{POSIXt}. Which
  generics have different behaviours for the two classes? Which generics
  share the same behaviour?
\end{enumerate}

\hypertarget{dispatch-details}{%
\section{Dispatch details}\label{dispatch-details}}

This chapter concludes with a few additional details about method
dispatch that is not well documented elsewhere. It is safe to skip these
details if you're new to S3.

\hypertarget{environments-and-namespaces}{%
\subsection{Environments and
namespaces}\label{environments-and-namespaces}}

The precise rules for where a generic looks for the methods are a little
complicated because there are two paths for discovery:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\item
  In the calling environment of the function that called the generic.
\item
  In the special \texttt{.\_\_S3MethodsTable\_\_.} object in the
  function environment of the generic. Every package has an
  \texttt{.\_\_S3MethodsTable\_\_} which lists all the S3 methods
  exported by the package.
\end{enumerate}

These details are not usually important, but are necessary in order for
S3 generics to find the correct method when the generic and method are
in different packages.

\hypertarget{s3-and-base-types}{%
\subsection{S3 and base types}\label{s3-and-base-types}}

What happens when you call an S3 generic with a non-S3 object, i.e.~an
object that doesn't have the class attribute set? You might think it
would dispatch on what \texttt{class()} returns:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{matrix}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\OperatorTok{:}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{))}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "matrix"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

But unfortunately dispatch actually occurs on the \textbf{implicit
class}, which has three components:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  ``array'' or ``matrix'' (if the object has dimensions).
\item
  \texttt{typeof()} (with a few minor tweaks).
\item
  If it's ``integer'' or ``double'', ``numeric''.
\end{itemize}

There is no base function that will compute the implicit class, but you
can use a helper from the sloop package: \index{implicit class}
\index{base types!implicit class}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{s3_class}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{matrix}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\OperatorTok{:}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{))}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "matrix"  "integer" "numeric"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\texttt{s3\_dispatch()} knows about the implicit class, so use it if
you're ever in doubt about method dispatch:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{s3_dispatch}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{matrix}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\OperatorTok{:}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{)))}
\CommentTok{#>    print.matrix}
\CommentTok{#>    print.integer}
\CommentTok{#>    print.numeric}
\CommentTok{#> -> print.default}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Note that this can lead to different dispatch for objects that look
similar:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{x1 <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{1}\OperatorTok{:}\DecValTok{5}
\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{(x1)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "integer"}
\KeywordTok{s3_dispatch}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{mean}\NormalTok{(x1))}
\CommentTok{#>    mean.integer}
\CommentTok{#>    mean.numeric}
\CommentTok{#> -> mean.default}

\NormalTok{x2 <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{structure}\NormalTok{(x1, }\DataTypeTok{class =} \StringTok{"integer"}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{(x2)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "integer"}
\KeywordTok{s3_dispatch}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{mean}\NormalTok{(x2))}
\CommentTok{#>    mean.integer}
\CommentTok{#> -> mean.default}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{internal-generics}{%
\subsection{Internal generics}\label{internal-generics}}

Some S3 generics, like \texttt{{[}}, \texttt{sum()}, and
\texttt{cbind()}, don't call \texttt{UseMethod()} because they are
implemented in C. Instead, they call the C functions
\texttt{DispatchGroup()} or \texttt{DispatchOrEval()}. These functions
are called \textbf{internal generics}, because they do dispatch
internally, in C code. Internal generics only exist in base R, so you
can not create an internal generic in a package.

\texttt{s3\_dispatch()} shows internal generics by including the name of
the generic at the bottom of the method class. If this method is called,
all the work happens in C code, typically using {[}switchpatch{]}.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{s3_dispatch}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{Sys.time}\NormalTok{()[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{])}
\CommentTok{#> -> [.POSIXct}
\CommentTok{#>    [.POSIXt}
\CommentTok{#>    [.default}
\CommentTok{#>  * [}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

For performance reasons, internal generics do not dispatch to methods
unless the class attribute has been set (\texttt{is.object()} is true).
This means that internal generics do not use the implicit class. Again,
if you're confused, rely on \texttt{s3\_dispatch()} to show you the
difference.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{x <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{sample}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{(x)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "integer"}
\KeywordTok{s3_dispatch}\NormalTok{(x[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{])}
\CommentTok{#>    [.integer}
\CommentTok{#>    [.numeric}
\CommentTok{#>    [.default}
\CommentTok{#> -> [}

\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{(y) }
\CommentTok{#> [1] "numeric"}
\KeywordTok{s3_dispatch}\NormalTok{(mtcars[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{])}
\CommentTok{#> -> [.data.frame}
\CommentTok{#>    [.default}
\CommentTok{#>  * [}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{group-generics}{%
\subsection{Group generics}\label{group-generics}}

Group generics are the most complicated part of S3 method dispatch
because they involve both \texttt{NextMethod()} and internal generics.
Group generics are worth learning about, however, because they allow you
to implement a whole swath of methods with one function. Like internal
generics, they only exist in base R, and you can not define your own
group generic.

Base R has four group generics, which are made up of the following
generics: \index{group generics} \index{S3!group generics}

\begin{itemize}
\item
  \textbf{Math}: \texttt{abs}, \texttt{sign}, \texttt{sqrt},
  \texttt{floor}, \texttt{cos}, \texttt{sin}, \texttt{log},
  \texttt{exp}, \ldots{}
\item
  \textbf{Ops}: \texttt{+}, \texttt{-}, \texttt{*}, \texttt{/},
  \texttt{\^{}}, \texttt{\%\%}, \texttt{\%/\%}, \texttt{\&},
  \texttt{\textbar{}}, \texttt{!}, \texttt{==}, \texttt{!=},
  \texttt{\textless{}}, \texttt{\textless{}=}, \texttt{\textgreater{}=},
  \texttt{\textgreater{}}
\item
  \textbf{Summary}: \texttt{all}, \texttt{any}, \texttt{sum},
  \texttt{prod}, \texttt{min}, \texttt{max}, \texttt{range}
\item
  \textbf{Complex}: \texttt{Arg}, \texttt{Conj}, \texttt{Im},
  \texttt{Mod}, \texttt{Re}
\end{itemize}

Defining a single group generic for your class overrides the default
behaviour for all of the members of the group. Methods for group
generics are looked for only if the methods for the specific generic do
not exist:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{s3_dispatch}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{sum}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{Sys.time}\NormalTok{()))}
\CommentTok{#>    sum.POSIXct}
\CommentTok{#>    sum.POSIXt}
\CommentTok{#>    sum.default}
\CommentTok{#> -> Summary.POSIXct}
\CommentTok{#>    Summary.POSIXt}
\CommentTok{#>    Summary.default}
\CommentTok{#>  * sum}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Most group generics involve a call to \texttt{NextMethod()}. For
example, take \texttt{difftime()} objects. If you look at the method
dispatch for \texttt{abs()}, you'll see there's a \texttt{Math} group
generic defined.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{y <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{as.difftime}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{units =} \StringTok{"mins"}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{s3_dispatch}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{abs}\NormalTok{(y))}
\CommentTok{#>    abs.difftime}
\CommentTok{#>    abs.default}
\CommentTok{#> -> Math.difftime}
\CommentTok{#>    Math.default}
\CommentTok{#>  * abs}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\texttt{Math.difftime} basically looks like this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{Math.difftime <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x, ...) \{}
  \KeywordTok{new_difftime}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{NextMethod}\NormalTok{(), }\DataTypeTok{units =} \KeywordTok{attr}\NormalTok{(x, }\StringTok{"units"}\NormalTok{))}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

It dispatches to the next method, here the internal default, to perform
the actual computation, then copies back over the the class and
attributes.

Note that inside a group generic function a special variable
\texttt{.Generic} provides the actual generic function called. This can
be useful when producing error messages, and can sometimes be useful if
you need to manually re-call the generic with different arguments.

\hypertarget{double-dispatch}{%
\subsection{Double dispatch}\label{double-dispatch}}

Generics in the ``Ops'' group, which includes the two-argument
mathematical and logical operators like \texttt{-} and \texttt{\&},
implement a special type of method dispatch. They dispatch on the type
of \emph{both} of the arguments, so called \textbf{double dispatch}.
This is necessary to preserve the commutative property of many
operators, i.e. \texttt{a\ +\ b} should equal \texttt{b\ +\ a}. Take the
following simple example:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{date <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{as.Date}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"2017-01-01"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{integer <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{1L}

\NormalTok{date }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{integer}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "2017-01-02"}
\NormalTok{integer }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{date}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "2017-01-02"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

If \texttt{+} dispatched only on the first argument, it would return
different values for the two cases. To overcome this problem, generics
in the Ops group use a slightly different strategy from usual. Rather
than doing a single method dispatch, they do two, one for each input.
There are three possible outcomes of this lookup:

\begin{itemize}
\item
  The methods are the same, so it doesn't matter which method is used.
\item
  The methods are different, and R calls the first method with a
  warning.
\item
  One method is internal, in which case R calls the other method.
\end{itemize}

For the example above, we can look at the possible methods for each
argument, taking advantage of the fact that we can call \texttt{+} with
a single argument. In this case, the second argument would dispatch to
the internal \texttt{+} function, so R will call \texttt{+.Date}.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{s3_dispatch}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{date)}
\CommentTok{#> -> +.Date}
\CommentTok{#>    +.default}
\CommentTok{#>  * Ops.Date}
\CommentTok{#>    Ops.default}
\CommentTok{#>  * +}
\KeywordTok{s3_dispatch}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{integer)}
\CommentTok{#>    +.integer}
\CommentTok{#>    +.numeric}
\CommentTok{#>    +.default}
\CommentTok{#>    Ops.integer}
\CommentTok{#>    Ops.numeric}
\CommentTok{#>    Ops.default}
\CommentTok{#> -> +}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Let's take a look at another case. What happens if you try to add a date
to a factor? There is no method in common, so R calls the internal
\texttt{+} method (which preserves the attributes of the LHS), with a
warning.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{factor <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{factor}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"a"}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{s3_dispatch}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{factor)}
\CommentTok{#>    +.factor}
\CommentTok{#>    +.default}
\CommentTok{#> -> Ops.factor}
\CommentTok{#>    Ops.default}
\CommentTok{#>  * +}

\NormalTok{date }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{factor}
\CommentTok{#> Warning: Incompatible methods ("+.Date", "Ops.factor") for "+"}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "2017-01-02"}
\NormalTok{factor }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{date}
\CommentTok{#> Warning: Incompatible methods ("Ops.factor", "+.Date") for "+"}
\CommentTok{#> Error in as.character.factor(x):}
\CommentTok{#>   malformed factor}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Finally, what happens if we try to substract a POSIXct from a POSIXlt? A
common \texttt{-.POSIXt} method is found and called.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{dt1 <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{as.POSIXct}\NormalTok{(date)}
\NormalTok{dt2 <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{as.POSIXlt}\NormalTok{(date)}

\KeywordTok{s3_dispatch}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{-}\NormalTok{dt1)}
\CommentTok{#>    -.POSIXct}
\CommentTok{#> -> -.POSIXt}
\CommentTok{#>    -.default}
\CommentTok{#>    Ops.POSIXct}
\CommentTok{#>  * Ops.POSIXt}
\CommentTok{#>    Ops.default}
\CommentTok{#>  * -}
\KeywordTok{s3_dispatch}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{-}\NormalTok{dt2)}
\CommentTok{#>    -.POSIXlt}
\CommentTok{#> -> -.POSIXt}
\CommentTok{#>    -.default}
\CommentTok{#>    Ops.POSIXlt}
\CommentTok{#>  * Ops.POSIXt}
\CommentTok{#>    Ops.default}
\CommentTok{#>  * -}

\NormalTok{dt1 }\OperatorTok{-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{dt2}
\CommentTok{#> Time difference of 0 secs}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{exercises-44}{%
\subsection{Exercises}\label{exercises-44}}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \texttt{Math.difftime()} is more complicated than I described. Why?
\end{enumerate}

\hypertarget{s4}{%
\chapter{S4}\label{s4}}

\hypertarget{introduction-12}{%
\section{Introduction}\label{introduction-12}}

Like S3, S4 implements functional OOP, but is much more rigorous and
strict. There are three main differences between S3 and S4:

\begin{itemize}
\item
  S4 classes have formal definitions provided by a call to
  \texttt{setClass()}. An S4 class can have multiple parents (multiple
  inheritance).
\item
  The fields of an S4 object are not attributes or named elements, but
  instead are called \textbf{slots} and are accessed with the special
  \texttt{@} operator.
\item
  Methods are not defined with a naming convention, but are instead
  defined by a call to \texttt{setMethod()}. S4 generics can dispatch on
  multiple arguments (multiple dispatch).
\end{itemize}

A good overview of the motivation of S4 and its historical context can
be found in Chambers and others
(\protect\hyperlink{ref-chambers-2014}{2014}),
\url{https://projecteuclid.org/download/pdfview_1/euclid.ss/1408368569}.

S4 is a rich system, and it's not possible to cover all of it in one
chapter. Instead, we'll focus on what you need to know to read most S4
code, and write basic S4 components. Unfortunately there is not one good
reference for S4 and as you move towards more advanced usage, you will
need to piece together needed information by carefully reading the
documentation and performing experiments. Some good places to start are:

\begin{itemize}
\item
  \href{https://bioconductor.org/help/course-materials/}{Bioconductor
  course materials}, a list of all courses taught by Bioconductor, a big
  user of S4. One recent (2017) course by Martin Morgan and Hervé Pagès
  is
  \href{https://bioconductor.org/help/course-materials/2017/Zurich/S4-classes-and-methods.html}{S4
  classes and methods}.
\item
  \href{http://stackoverflow.com/search?tab=votes\&q=user\%3a547331\%20\%5bs4\%5d\%20is\%3aanswe}{S4
  questions on stackoverflow} answered by Martin Morgan.
\item
  \href{http://amzn.com/0387759352?tag=devtools-20}{\emph{Software for
  Data Analysis}}, a book by John Chambers.
\end{itemize}

\hypertarget{outline-10}{%
\subsection*{Outline}\label{outline-10}}
\addcontentsline{toc}{subsection}{Outline}

\hypertarget{prerequisites-7}{%
\subsection*{Prerequisites}\label{prerequisites-7}}
\addcontentsline{toc}{subsection}{Prerequisites}

All S4 related functions live in the methods package. This package is
always available when you're running R interactively, but may not be
available when running R in batch mode (i.e.~from \texttt{Rscript}). For
this reason, it's a good idea to call \texttt{library(methods)} whenever
you use S4. This also signals to the reader that you'll be using the S4
object system.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(methods)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{classes-1}{%
\section{Classes}\label{classes-1}}

Unlike S3, S4 classes have a formal definition. To define an S4 class,
you must define three key properties:

\begin{itemize}
\item
  The class \textbf{name}. By convention, S4 class names use
  UpperCamelCase.
\item
  A named character vector that describes the names and classes of the
  \textbf{slots} (fields). For example, a person might be represented by
  a character name and a numeric age:
  \texttt{c(name\ =\ "character",\ age\ =\ "numeric")}. The pseudo-class
  ``ANY'' allows a slot to accept objects of any type. \index{slots}
\item
  The name of a class (or classes) to inherit behaviour from, or in S4
  terminology, the classes that it \textbf{contains}.
\end{itemize}

Slots and contains can specify the names of S4 classes, S3 classes (if
registered), and base types. We'll go into more detail about non-S4
classes at the end of the chapter, in
\protect\hyperlink{s4-and-existing-code}{S4 and existing code}.

To create a class, you call \texttt{setClass()}, supplying these three
properties. Lets make this concrete with an example. Here we create two
classes: a person with character \texttt{name} and numeric \texttt{age},
and an \texttt{Employee} that inherits slots and methods from
\texttt{Person}, adding an additional \texttt{boss} slot that must be a
\texttt{Person}. \texttt{setClass()} returns a low-level constructor
function, which should be given the class name with a \texttt{.} prefix.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{.Person <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{setClass}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Person"}\NormalTok{, }
  \DataTypeTok{slots =} \KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}
    \DataTypeTok{name =} \StringTok{"character"}\NormalTok{, }
    \DataTypeTok{age =} \StringTok{"numeric"}
\NormalTok{  )}
\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{.Employee <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{setClass}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Employee"}\NormalTok{, }
  \DataTypeTok{contains =} \StringTok{"Person"}\NormalTok{, }
  \DataTypeTok{slots =} \KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}
    \DataTypeTok{boss =} \StringTok{"Person"}
\NormalTok{  )}
\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\texttt{setClass()} has 10 other arguments, but they are all either
deprecated or not recommended. If you have existing S4 code that uses
them, I'd recommend carefully reading the documentation and upgrading to
modern practice.

We can now use the constructor to create an object from that class:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{hadley <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{.Person}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{name =} \StringTok{"Hadley"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{age =} \DecValTok{37}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{hadley}
\CommentTok{#> An object of class "Person"}
\CommentTok{#> Slot "name":}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "Hadley"}
\CommentTok{#> }
\CommentTok{#> Slot "age":}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 37}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

It's also possible to create an instance using \texttt{new()} and the
name of the class. This is not recommended because it introduces some
ambiguity. What happens if there are two packages that both define the
\texttt{Person} class?

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{hadley2 <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{new}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Person"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{name =} \StringTok{"Hadley"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{age =} \DecValTok{37}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

In most programming languages, class definition occurs at compile-time,
and object construction occurs later, at run-time. In R, however, both
definition and construction occur at run time. When you call
\texttt{setClass()}, you are registering a class definition in a
(hidden) global variable. As with all state-modifying functions you need
to use \texttt{setClass()} with care. It's possible to create invalid
objects if you redefine a class after already having instantiated an
object:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{.A <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{setClass}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"A"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{slots =} \KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{x =} \StringTok{"numeric"}\NormalTok{))}
\NormalTok{a <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{.A}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{x =} \DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{.A <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{setClass}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"A"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{slots =} \KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{a_different_slot =} \StringTok{"numeric"}\NormalTok{))}
\NormalTok{a}
\CommentTok{#> An object of class "A"}
\CommentTok{#> Slot "a_different_slot":}
\CommentTok{#> Error in slot(object, what):}
\CommentTok{#>   no slot of name "a_different_slot" for this object of class "A"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This isn't usually a problem, because you'll define a class once, then
leave the definition alone. If you want to enforce a single class
definition, you can ``seal'' it:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{setClass}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Sealed"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{sealed =} \OtherTok{TRUE}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{setClass}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Sealed"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> Error in setClass("Sealed"):}
\CommentTok{#>   "Sealed" has a sealed class definition and cannot be redefined}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{slots}{%
\subsection{Slots}\label{slots}}

You can access the slots with \texttt{@} or \texttt{slot()}: \texttt{@}
is equivalent to \texttt{\$}, and \texttt{slot()} to \texttt{{[}{[}}.
\index{subsetting!S4} \index{S4!subsetting}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{hadley}\OperatorTok{@}\NormalTok{age}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 37}
\KeywordTok{slot}\NormalTok{(hadley, }\StringTok{"age"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 37}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

You can list all available slots with \texttt{slotNames()}:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{slotNames}\NormalTok{(hadley)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "name" "age"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Slots should be considered an internal implementation detail. That
means:

\begin{itemize}
\item
  As a user, you should not reach into someone else's object with
  \texttt{@}, but instead, look for a method that provides the
  information you want.
\item
  As a developer, you should make sure that all public facing slots have
  their own accessor methods.
\end{itemize}

We'll come back how to implement accessors in {[}Accessors{]}, once
you've learned how S4 generics and methods work.

\hypertarget{helper}{%
\subsection{Helper}\label{helper}}

The result of \texttt{setClass()} is a low-level constructor, which
means that don't need to write one yourself. However, this default
constructor has three drawbacks:

\begin{itemize}
\item
  The constructor takes \texttt{...}, not individual named slots. This
  mean that printing the function is not revealing, and autocomplete
  doesn't have the\\
  data it needs to be helpful.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{.Person}
\CommentTok{#> class generator function for class "Person" from package '.GlobalEnv'}
\CommentTok{#> function (...) }
\CommentTok{#> new("Person", ...)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\item
  If you don't supply values for a slot, the constructor will
  automatically supply a default value:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{.Person}\NormalTok{()}
\CommentTok{#> An object of class "Person"}
\CommentTok{#> Slot "name":}
\CommentTok{#> character(0)}
\CommentTok{#> }
\CommentTok{#> Slot "age":}
\CommentTok{#> numeric(0)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

  Here, you might prefer that \texttt{name} is required, or that
  \texttt{age} defaults to \texttt{NA}.
\item
  While it's not possible to create an S4 object with the wrong slots or
  slots of the wrong type:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{.Person}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{name =} \StringTok{"Hadley"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{age =} \StringTok{"thirty"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> Error in validObject(.Object):}
\CommentTok{#>   invalid class "Person" object: invalid object for slot "age" in class "Person": got class "character", should be or extend class "numeric"}
\KeywordTok{.Person}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{name =} \StringTok{"Hadley"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{sex =} \StringTok{"male"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> Error in initialize(value, ...):}
\CommentTok{#>   invalid name for slot of class "Person": sex}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

  It is possible to create slots with the wrong lengths, or otherwise
  invalid values:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{.Person}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{name =} \StringTok{"Hadley"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{age =} \KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{37}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{99}\NormalTok{))}
\CommentTok{#> An object of class "Person"}
\CommentTok{#> Slot "name":}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "Hadley"}
\CommentTok{#> }
\CommentTok{#> Slot "age":}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 37 99}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\end{itemize}

Like with S3, we resolve these issues by writing a helper function.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{Person <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(name, }\DataTypeTok{age =} \OtherTok{NULL}\NormalTok{, ...) \{}
  \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ (}\KeywordTok{is.null}\NormalTok{(age)) \{}
\NormalTok{    age <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{rep}\NormalTok{(}\OtherTok{NA_real_}\NormalTok{, }\KeywordTok{length}\NormalTok{(name))}
\NormalTok{  \}}
  
  \KeywordTok{stopifnot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{length}\NormalTok{(name) }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{length}\NormalTok{(age))}
  \KeywordTok{.Person}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{name =}\NormalTok{ name, }\DataTypeTok{age =}\NormalTok{ age)}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This provides the behaviour that we want:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{# Name is now required}
\KeywordTok{Person}\NormalTok{()}
\CommentTok{#> Error in Person():}
\CommentTok{#>   argument "name" is missing, with no default}

\CommentTok{# And name and age must have same length}
\KeywordTok{Person}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Hadley"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{age =} \KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{30}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{37}\NormalTok{))}
\CommentTok{#> Error in Person("Hadley", age = c(30, 37)):}
\CommentTok{#>   length(name) == length(age) is not TRUE}

\CommentTok{# And if not supplied, age gets a default value of NA}
\KeywordTok{Person}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Hadley"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> An object of class "Person"}
\CommentTok{#> Slot "name":}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "Hadley"}
\CommentTok{#> }
\CommentTok{#> Slot "age":}
\CommentTok{#> [1] NA}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

It is \emph{possible} to achieve the same effect by implementing an
\texttt{initialize()} method, but the \texttt{initialize()} generic has
a complicated contract and it is very hard to get all the details right.

To re-use checking code in a subclass, you can take advantage of a
detail of the constructor: an unnamed argument is interpreted as
predefined object from the parent class. For example, to define a
constructor for the Employee class that reuses the Person helper, you
first create a \texttt{Person()}, then pass that to the
\texttt{.Employee} constructor.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{Employee <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(name, age, boss) \{}
\NormalTok{  person <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{Person}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{name =}\NormalTok{ name, }\DataTypeTok{age =}\NormalTok{ age)}
  \KeywordTok{.Employee}\NormalTok{(person, }\DataTypeTok{boss =}\NormalTok{ boss)}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

As with S3, if the validity checking code is lengthy or expensive, you
should pull it out into a separate function which the helper calls.

\hypertarget{introspection}{%
\subsection{Introspection}\label{introspection}}

To determine what classes an object inherits from, use \texttt{is()}:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{is}\NormalTok{(hadley)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "Person"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

To test if an object inherits from a specific class, use the second
argument of \texttt{is()}:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{is}\NormalTok{(hadley, }\StringTok{"person"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] FALSE}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

If you are using a class provided by a package you can get help on it
with \texttt{class?Person}.

\hypertarget{exercises-45}{%
\subsection{Exercises}\label{exercises-45}}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\item
  What happens if you define a new S4 class that doesn't ``contain'' an
  existing class? (Hint: read about virtual classes in
  \texttt{?setClass}.)
\item
  Imagine you were going to reimplement ordered factors, dates, and data
  frames in S4. Sketch out the \texttt{setClass()} calls that you would
  use to define the classes. What should they inherit from? What slots
  should they use?
\end{enumerate}

\hypertarget{generics-and-methods-1}{%
\section{Generics and methods}\label{generics-and-methods-1}}

The job of a generic is to perform method dispatch, i.e.~find the method
designed to handle the combination of classes passed to the generic.
Here you'll learn how to define S4 generics and methods, then in the
next section we'll explore precisely how S4 method dispatch works.

S4 generics have a similar structure to S3 generics, but are a little
more formal. To create an new S4 generic, you call \texttt{setGeneric()}
with a function that calls \texttt{standardGeneric()}.
\index{S4!generics} \index{S4!methods} \index{generics!S4}
\index{methods!S4}.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{setGeneric}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"myGeneric"}\NormalTok{, }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x) }\KeywordTok{standardGeneric}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"myGeneric"}\NormalTok{))}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Note that it is bad practice to use \texttt{\{} in the generic function.
This triggers a special case that is more expensive, and generally best
avoided.

Like \texttt{setClass()}, \texttt{setGeneric()} has many other
arguments. There is only one that you need to know about:
\texttt{signature}. This allows you to control the arguments that are
used for method dispatch. If \texttt{signature} is not supplied, all
arguments (apart from \texttt{...}) are used. It is occassionally useful
to remove arguments from dispatch. This allows you to require that
methods provide arguments like \texttt{verbose\ =\ TRUE} or
\texttt{quiet\ =\ FALSE}, but they don't take part in dispatch.

A generic isn't useful without some methods, and in S4 you add methods
with \texttt{setMethod()}. There are three important arguments: the name
of the generic, the name of the class, and the method itself.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{setMethod}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"myGeneric"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Person"}\NormalTok{, }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x) \{}
  \CommentTok{# method implementation}
\NormalTok{\})}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

(Again, just like \texttt{setClass()}, \texttt{setMethod()} has other
arguments, but you should never use them.)

\hypertarget{show-method}{%
\subsection{Show method}\label{show-method}}

As with S3, the most commonly defined S4 method controls printing, but
in S4 we use a different generic: \texttt{show()}.

When defining a method for an existing generic, you need to first
determine the arguments. You can get those from the documentation or by
looking at the formals of the generic:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{names}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{formals}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{getGeneric}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"show"}\NormalTok{)))}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "object"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Our show method needs to have a single argument \texttt{object}:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{setMethod}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"show"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Person"}\NormalTok{, }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(object) \{}
  \KeywordTok{cat}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{is}\NormalTok{(object)[[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{]], }\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{,}
      \StringTok{"  Name: "}\NormalTok{, object}\OperatorTok{@}\NormalTok{name, }\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{,}
      \StringTok{"  Age:  "}\NormalTok{, object}\OperatorTok{@}\NormalTok{age, }\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{,}
      \DataTypeTok{sep =} \StringTok{""}
\NormalTok{  )}
\NormalTok{\})}
\NormalTok{hadley}
\CommentTok{#> Person}
\CommentTok{#>   Name: Hadley}
\CommentTok{#>   Age:  37}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

More formally, the second argument to \texttt{setMethod()} is called the
\textbf{signature}. In S4, unlike S3, the signature can include multiple
arguments. This makes method dispatch in S4 substantially more
complicated, but avoids having to implement double-dispatch as a special
case. We'll talk more about multiple dispatch in the next section.

\hypertarget{accessor-methods}{%
\subsection{Accessor methods}\label{accessor-methods}}

Slots are generally considered to be an internal implementation detail:
they can change without warning and user code should avoid accessing
them directly. Instead, all user-readble slots should get an
\textbf{accessor}. If the slot is unique to the class, this can just be
a function:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{person_name <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x) x}\OperatorTok{@}\NormalTok{name}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

But typically, you will want to define a generic and provide a method
for your class:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{setGeneric}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"name"}\NormalTok{, }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x) }\KeywordTok{standardGeneric}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"name"}\NormalTok{))}
\KeywordTok{setMethod}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"name"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Person"}\NormalTok{, }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x) x}\OperatorTok{@}\NormalTok{name)}
